schedule.topic: Course overview and goals, logistics, software, introduction to computing and to computers

Basic Python: programming languages, primitive scalar object types, basic operators, variables and assignment, casting and conversions, syntactic and semantic errors, notion of functions, basic style rules
Lab: How to use the Spyder editor, experimenting with basic python concepts, solving problems, code debugging, Autolab and Autograder
Non-scalar data types, strings: Binary representations, character encoding, strings data types, quoting, operators, operator overloading, indexing

Strings and Boolean data types, conditionals : Operations on strings (length, indexing, slicing, replacing, finding), conversions, boolean variables, relational operators, logical operators, flow control using conditional constructs, indentation and scoping
Lab: Use of all primitive data types, operators (numeric, relational, logical) program branching and decision-making using conditionals
schedule.notes: Textbook Chapters 2 and 5 (except sections using Lists)

schedule.topic: Non-scalar data types, lists: data structures, tuples, mutability and lists, general access and modification operations on lists, indexing and slicing, aliasing effects

Non-scalar data types, lists: mutability vs. immutability, aliasing vs. cloning, retrieving, adding, and removing elements, slicing and cloning, operator overloading and concatenation, utility methods and functions available for lists, key function for comparison
Lab: Operations on and manipulation of lists data types
Iteration: Repeated actions using for loops (definite loops), range(), scoping, examples of typical use, continue statement
Iteration: break statement, scope of variables, nested loops, matrix data structure, while loops (indefinite loops), use of sentinel variables, never ending loops
Lab: Flow control using while and for loops, variable scope
schedule.notes: Textbook Chapter 4, first section, and Chapter 7, second section

schedule.topic: Functions for decomposition, abstraction, and reusability: functions as subprograms, function definition, functions for task decomposition, code modularity and code reusability, arguments, local scoping, stack frames, returning values, modifying arguments
Sports Day
Lab: Functions, use positional, keyword, and arbitrary number of arguments, returning and modifying values, scopes

Functions for decomposition, abstraction, and reusability: abstraction, specifications, documenting a function with docstrings, inline comments, creating and using modules, import statements, dot notation, useful modules (numpy, math)
Preparation to the midterm exam I: Overview and practice of topics so far, (better) use of Spyder, Q&A
MIDTERM EXAM I: All topics considered so far in the course
Associative data types, dictionaries: creating labeled data using dictionaries, lists vs. dictionaries, type restrictions, initialization, access, updating, removal of entries
Non-scalar data types, multi-dimensional arrays: lists to represent multi-dimensional data arrays, use of the Numpy module, applications in numeric linear algebra and image processing
Regular expressions for searching patterns in strings: Re module, character groups, quantifiers, extraction, position, finding multiple matches

Dictionaries, Sets: dictionaries as hashed types, modalities for creating dictionaries, accessing, adding, modifying and removing items using class methods, methods for inspecting a dictionary, view objects, iterating over the items and over the keys, useful operations on dictionary data, definition of sets, sets vs. lists vs. dictionaries, modalities for creating a set, operations on sets, available methods and functions

schedule.topic: Lab: Use of dictionaries and sets for structuring and searching data
Spring Break
Spring Break
Spring Break
I/O with files: Data storage and files, storage media, text and binary files, opening and closing files, record structure, reading files, writing text files

I/O with files: Output string formatting with str.format, interaction with the filesystem, exceptions and assertions: operations on the file system with the os module, exceptions and assertions, file exceptions, try-except-else-finally construct, flow control
Lab: Using I/O from/to files to process, store, and share information
Downloading, manipulating, and sharing data: CSV data format, downloading and parsing CSV files using csv module

Object-oriented programming: general concepts behind object-oriented design and programming, abstract data types and classes, methods, object instantiation, designing modular and reusable programs using abstract data types, constructor-initializer-destructor, self reference variable

Recursion, Divide-and-conquer paradigm: recursive definitions, recursion in computing, base ad recursive cases, advantages and challenges, management of stack frames, memoization, decrease-and-conquer vs. divide-and-conquer, examples (factorial, exponentiation, list tree, Fibonacci numbers, binary search, fractals)

Project description, data visualization using Matplotlib: overview, main functionalities, data plotting, example of a class for data management, inspection and visualization
Data visualization and animation using Matplotlib: creating graphs to analyse data
Lab: Use of Matplotlib for data visualization
Monte Carlo Simulation: concepts behind Monte Carlo simulation techniques, gambling game example, random number generation in a computer, random module, visualization examples
Monte Carlo Simulation: more examples of use of random numbers and Monte Carlo, estimate of pi, complex visualizations, computing areas, numpy methods
Lab: Monte Carlo simulation, use of random numbers, visualization
Combinatorial models: knapsack optimization problems, practical applications, greedy approaches, dynamic programming approach, complexity
